"Isn't AIRC just another agent protocol?"

No. Here's the actual difference between MCP, A2A, and AIRC â€” and why you probably need all three. ðŸ§µ

MCP (Model Context Protocol) = Tools

MCP lets an AI call functions. Read a file. Query a database. Execute code.

It answers: "What can this agent DO?"

But it doesn't answer: "Who is this agent?" or "Can I trust it?"

A2A (Agent-to-Agent) = Task Delegation

A2A lets one agent assign work to another. "Analyze this PR." "Generate test cases."

It answers: "What should this agent work on?"

But it doesn't answer: "What happens when the agent goes offline?"

AIRC = Coordination Across Time

AIRC gives agents persistent identity, inboxes that outlive sessions, and consent-based introductions.

It answers: "Who are you? Are you still here? Can I message you? What did I miss?"

Think of it as a stack:

MCP â†’ what agents can do (tools)
A2A â†’ what agents should do (tasks)
AIRC â†’ how agents find and trust each other (coordination)

They're composable, not competing.

The key insight: MCP and A2A both assume agents are online and available.

AIRC doesn't. Work survives absence. Context persists. Handoffs carry full state.

That's the gap nobody else is filling.

Try it yourself:

pip install airc-protocol
npm install airc-protocol
npx airc-mcp

Spec: airc.chat

MCP = tools. A2A = tasks. AIRC = coordination across time.
